commit.message:
Look for unit tests in target/debug/deps

I do not know when cargo started putting the unit tests under
target/debug/deps instead of target/deps (where we were looking for
before) but that seems to be how things work now.

Rename identity_conversion to useless_conversion

This check's name has changed in Clippy so adjust it accordingly to avoid
inaccurate warnings that break the build.

Delay format calls in error contexts

It turns out that string formatting is quite expensive as part of mapping
operations (surprise!) and we were doing some unnecessary calls to construct
error messages that are never used.  So, instead of using cause(), switch
to using with_cause() so that we can delay the calls to format!() to when
they are strictly needed.

Should cut about 15% of the CPU time spent within map operations per the
measurements done by @beasleyr-vmw.

Fixes #111.

Announce 0.2.0

As part of this change, clean up the release notes and add markdownlint
settings for VSCode that helped these changes.
Use Bazel 3.0.0 now that it's released

Remove usage of bazil.org/fuse

Upstream has dropped support for macOS and we were only using them for an
unmount call anyway.  Reimplement our own version.

Adopt go modules

This allows us to remove some logic in the configure script to download
unversioned packages and to fix some problems I was observing with the
VSCode integration.

As part of this, pin bazil.org/fuse to a version that still works on
macOS and go 1.12.  I'll be removing this soon anyway.

commit.message:
Make unmap actually delete inodes

We must do this to keep sandboxfs memory usage under control.

During a large ObjC build from Bazel, I noticed sandboxfs growing to
50GB because that build creates thousands of very large sandboxes.
Even if the build unmaps each of them as it's done with each action,
sandboxfs was keeping track of all inodes.  With this change, memory
consumption drops to a few hundred MBs during the same build.

Refactor how we handle inode operations

Instead of intermixing calls to the nodes and error handling inside the
implementation of the vnops, add helper functions that return Result
objects and make the vnops simply deal with the kernel replies.

Other than making the code simpler to follow, I'm doing this because
find_node will need to change to support returning errors (once I fix
unmap to actually erase nodes).  Once that happens, having to add extra
error logic everywhere will be brittle and make things even harder to
follow.

And to prove this, I've simplified all the logic that called find_node
and then verified if the nodes were writable behind a find_writable_node
call that returns a Result.

Move errors to their own module

This is to allow using KernelError in lib.rs without having to move its
definition to this file, which is already too long.

Merge pull request #107 from jmmv/protocol

This branch delivers a full rewrite of the reconfiguration protocol
in sandboxfs to offer better build performance for sandboxfs-based
sandboxes in Bazel.

commit.message:
Test against bazel 3.0.0rc2

This is the first release with proper support for the sandboxfs 0.2.0
protocol, so start using it to validate our integration with Bazel.

While doing this, bump the timeouts for the install phase, as we now
need to download some larger artifacts, and make sure that the install
phase downloads everything we need (without postponing downloads to
the build phase).  Unfortunately, I've had to disable the osx build
because I was unable to fit it within Travis' timeout.

Add aliases and defaults for reconfig messages

Further minimize the size of reconfiguration requests by adding short
aliases to all fields in the JSON protocol.  Also tag some fields as
default so that the common case needn't be specified.

Use prefix encoding for paths

Minimize reconfiguration requests by encoding paths as a pair of a prefix
identifier and a basename.  The prefix identifier is simply a number that
points to a path, so that the same number can be reused for all paths in
the same directory.

Prefixes are valid for the entire duration of a sandboxfs session so that
different configuration requests can refer to previously-defined prefixes.
Each request can then introduce new prefixes.

Process reconfigurations in parallel

Reconfiguration operations are, unfortunately, not in-memory only at this
point given that they require stating the file system mappings in order
to create the nodes.

Because of this, processing reconfiguration operations is not quick, and
if we process them serially, we penalize the parallelism that the caller
might have (primarily Bazel).

To address this, use a configurable number of threads to apply the
reconfigurations, and process each request in a separate thread.

In the future, we should try to avoiding any I/O during reconfiguration
operations.  To do this, we need to make node creation only require a
type, not the whole file metadata, which in turn requires making the
getattr operation lazy and extending the protocol to carry the node types
(which Bazel might already know).

Simplify reconfigurations to deal with sandboxes

Stop the recent madness that went into the reconfiguration protocol and
vastly simplify it by reducing its power.  Instead of dealing with paths
to map and unmap, deal with "sandboxes", which are just top-level
directories within the mount point that contain mappings.

This strips power off from sandboxfs, but nothing of value is lost: I
cannot imagine a case where arbitrary reconfigurations are useful, and
this makes the whole thing simpler.

Remove tests for invalidations

We do not have support for kernel cache invalidations and these tests have
been disabled for a while.  Remove them to facilitate maintenance of the
reconfiguration tests, and also because I'm pretty sure those tests would
be broken at this point even if invalidations worked.

Pair requests and their responses with a tag

Add a tag to each request, provided by the caller, that is propagated to the
corresponding response.  This will let us process requests in parallel.

Optimize reconfigs by avoiding root dir contention

All reconfiguration map/unmap requests used to go through the root directory,
which means that each path mapping and unmapping required taking its lock.
As it turns out, this causes contention when handling very large reconfigs in
parallel (duh), as Bazel likes to trigger.

To fix this, take advantage of the new reconfiguration protocol, which groups
mappings by subdirectory (aka "root").  We can now traverse the root directory
only once, looking for that subdirectory, and then handle all mappings within
it without disturbing the root.

Use snake case for JSON mappings

The reason JSON mappings used CamelCase in their field names is historical
and dates back to when the protocol was first introduced in Go.

Given that I've already changed the protocol for various other reasons, it
doesn't hurt to also fix this legacy issue and use snake case plus the same
internal names we use now for each mapping part.

I'm keeping Map and Unmap in CamelCase because they represent something
else (an "RPC"), which feels like a different thing than a field.

Tag map and unmap reconfigs with a root directory

This turns each map and unmap reconfiguration step into a list of
mappings, all tagged with a single "root" directory. All mappings in
the same step start in the same directory.

This will allow us to make reconfiguration operations much more efficient
by skipping the lookup of the root directory for each entry to apply.

Rewrite reconfig fatal error tests in Rust

I had already done this work for another unrelated change and the resulting
tests are faster and easier to deal with.

Turn reconfiguration protocol into JSON streams

For reconfiguration requests, remove the line-based protocol that expected
one request per line followed by a blank line and replace it with a stream
of JSON messages.

For reconfiguration resposes, remove the text-based answering mechanism
and replace it with a stream of JSON messages as well.

As a side-effect of this change, we cannot really tolerate invalid input
any longer as there is no way to recover the stream once that happens.
Therefore, any invalid input results in a fatal error that causes sandboxfs
to stop accepting reconfigurations.
Fix newly-raised clippy::skip-while-next warning
Add a lint check to validate line lengths

commit.message:
Silence sandboxfs output in tests that pass

Capture the stdout and stderr outputs of sandboxfs and only dump them to the
console if the test fails.  This makes it much easier to scan the output of
the test log when things do fail.

Suppress "cat" errors in tests

We invoke "cat" to determine if the mount cookie exists, and because we do
this immediately after invoking sandboxfs, the first invocation almost always
fails.  This results in test log pollution, which is pretty annoying.  Avoid
this by simply ignoring the output of these invocations.
